channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: In Istanbul, Optimism Fades to a Familiar Melancholy
item.media:description: A pro-government demonstration in Istanbul on Monday. The president consolidated his power in the city after a failed coup.
item.description: The coup attempt showed Istanbul to be perhaps Turkey’s most important city, but it is enveloped by a deep unease about terrorism, refugees and gentrification.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Air Transat Pilots Pulled From Jet and Arrested on Suspicion of Being Drunk
item.description: The flight to Toronto from Glasgow was delayed more than 20 hours, and passengers seemed to display relief as well as outrage.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: ISIS Claims Responsibility for Ax Attack on German Train
item.media:description: Police officers searched for evidence near Würzburg, Germany, on Tuesday, a day after an Afghan youth attacked passengers with an ax and a knife.
item.description: Investigators said they had found a hand-drawn Islamic State flag in the assailant’s room, though a firm connection with the group has not been established.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Airstrikes on ISIS-Held Villages in Syria Kill 56, Activists Say
item.description: Residents in the area blamed the American-led coalition for the bombings of Tokhar and Hoshariyeh, which are near an Islamic State stronghold.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: To France From Israel: Lessons on Living With Terror
item.media:description: City Hall in Tel Aviv was lit with the colors of the French flag on Friday to honor the victims of the attack in Nice.
item.description: A truck plowing through a crowd in Nice? Israeli citizens, security officials and experts say they’ve lived with, and planned for, such threats for decades.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER and JAMES GLANZ

item.title: Bangladesh, Blaming Local Groups for Attacks, Seeks Suspects Tied to ISIS
item.media:description: A police checkpoint along a road leading to the Holey Artisan Bakery, the site of a deadly attack this month in Dhaka, Bangladesh.
item.description: A list of suspects released after the Dhaka cafe siege includes men that the police have long sought as operatives for the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY and MAHER SATTAR
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Clash of Values Emerges After Afghan Child Bride Burns to Death
item.media:description: An Afghan policeman on Monday guarded a morgue in Kabul where the body of Zahra, married, pregnant and said to be 14 — though some said 17 — was held after she died from burns.
item.description: Troubles began for Zahra, a promising schoolgirl, when she was bartered away at age 11 and later married off. Her father said she was 14 and pregnant when she died.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: Byron Lima Oliva, Bishop’s Killer, Dies in Attack at Guatemala Prison
item.media:description: Byron Lima Oliva in 2012. Mr. Lima, convicted in the 1998 murder of Bishop Juan José Gerardi, built a criminal operation in prison, prosecutors said.
item.description: Mr. Lima, who was convicted in a 1998 murder and accused of building a criminal operation in prison, was killed along with 12 others, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN and NIC WIRTZ
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Memo From Brazil: Leader’s Poems Grip Brazilians, but Not in a ‘Fiery Flames’ Way
item.media:description: The poetry of Michel Temer, the interim president of Brazil, has become a welcome distraction for Brazilians in the midst of political turmoil.
item.description: Amid political turmoil, the poetry of Michel Temer has become a welcome source of amusement — and offers insight into the man now at the country’s helm.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Philippines Clears Gloria Macapagal Arroyo, Ex-President, of Graft Charges
item.media:description: The former president of the Philippines, Gloria Macapagal Arroyo, who has been detained since 2012, was allowed to vote in Lubao, north of Manila, in May.
item.description: The Supreme Court also ordered that Mrs. Arroyo be released from a Manila hospital where she has been detained since 2012.
item.dc:creator: FLOYD WHALEY

item.title: Sinosphere: Liberal Chinese Journal’s Purged Editors Declare Publication Dissolved
item.media:description: Du Daozheng, who was removed last week as publisher of Yanhuang Chunqiu, in the journal’s office in Beijing in 2009.
item.media:credit: Shiho Fukada for The New York Times
item.description: The journal, Yanhuang Chunqiu, has carried articles advocating political change and examining delicate issues in Chinese Communist history.
item.dc:creator: KIKI ZHAO

item.title: Sinosphere: KFC Targeted in Protests Over South China Sea
item.media:description: Members of a pro-Beijing political party demonstrating outside the United States Embassy in Hong Kong last week following a ruling in The Hague against Beijing’s claims in the South China Sea.
item.description: Accusing the United States of encouraging a case against China’s maritime claims, demonstrators called for boycotts in about a dozen cities.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Putin’s Swift Reaction to Doping Report Blames Anti-Russian Politics
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin responded unusually quickly to a World Anti-Doping Agency report that accused his government of running a covert doping program for the country’s Olympians.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: North Korea Fires 3 Missiles After U.S. and South Agree to Defense System
item.media:description: The leader of North Korea, Kim Jong-un, at the party congress in Pyongyang, the capital, in May.
item.description: Days after the United States and South Korea agreed to deploy an advanced missile defense system, North Korea fired three ballistic missiles.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: China Begins Air Patrols Over Disputed Area of the South China Sea
item.media:description: A Chinese H-6K bomber patrolling over the South China Sea in an undated photo released by Xinhua, the state news agency.
item.description: The patrols, seen as an assertion of sovereignty, were anticipated by analysts after an international tribunal ruled that Beijing had no legal right to the area.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: In Egypt, Many Leaders Quietly Cheered Turkish Coup Plotters
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey at a funeral service for a victim of the thwarted coup in Istanbul. The four-fingered salute is associated with the 2013 massacre of hundreds of supporters of Egypt’s ousted president, Mohamed Morsi.
item.description: “Many public figures,” one member of Parliament said, would be happy to see President Recep Tayyip Erdogan removed so that Egypt could have “a better relationship with Turkey.”
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: News Crackdown in Kashmir Leaves Locals ‘Surrounded by Rumors’
item.media:description: A protest in Srinagar, Kashmir’s summer capital, on Monday. A strict curfew remained in effect in troubled areas.
item.description: The authorities have blocked the mobile internet, prepaid cellphones and cable television stations, and banned the publication of newspapers.
item.dc:creator: NIDA NAJAR and HARI KUMAR

item.title: Theresa May Wins Vote to Renew Britain’s Nuclear Program
item.media:description: The Royal Navy submarine Vengeance, a Vanguard-class boat equipped with the Trident nuclear missile system.
item.media:credit: British Ministry of Defense, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.description: The new prime minister gained approval from Parliament to authorize and update the weapons system, a move intended as a signal that Britain remains a world power.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: Trilobites: South African Telescope Spots 1,300 Unknown Galaxies
item.media:description: Left: A patch of sky about as big as the full moon where the MeerKAT telescope discerned the radio glow of about 200 galaxies. Only a few (circled) had been previously observed; Right: A distant galaxy with an explosive core powered by a black hole.
item.description: The distant galaxies were recorded by a set of 16 antennas that will eventually be a part of the largest telescope ever built on Earth.
item.dc:creator: DENNIS OVERBYE

item.title: 4 Kenyan Policemen Charged in Deaths of Lawyer, Client and Driver
item.description: The three men vanished after the lawyer, Willie Kimani, filed a complaint on behalf of his client, Josphat Mwenda, alleging that he had been shot and wounded by the police.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Moment of Silence Turns Into Outcry Against Government After Nice Attack
item.media:description: Employees of the Negresco Hotel observed a minute of silence on Monday in Nice, France, to honor victims of the Bastille Day attack.
item.description: Anger in connection with the Nice attack is a product of accumulated frustration with the French government’s response to terrorism.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN and AURELIEN BREEDEN
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Gunman Stages Deadly Attack on Police Station in Kazakhstan
item.media:description: Police officers detained a suspect in an armed attack at a police station in Almaty, Kazakhstan, on Monday.
item.description: Three officers and two civilians were killed in Almaty, the country’s largest city, in an assault described as blending criminal and radical Islamist motivations.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Vast Purge in Turkey as Thousands Are Detained in Post-Coup Backlash
item.media:description: A funeral in Ankara, Turkey, on Monday for one of the victims of the recent coup attempt.
item.description: The Interior Ministry fired nearly 9,000 police officers on Monday, officials said, coming after the arrests of 6,000 military personnel and suspensions of nearly 3,000 judges.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO, CEYLAN YEGINSU and BEN HUBBARD
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Hostage Standoff at Yerevan Police Building in Armenia Enters 2nd Day
item.media:description: Officers securing the area around a police building in Yerevan, Armenia, on Sunday that was attacked by militants. Five people are believed to be held hostage.
item.media:credit: Aram Kirakosyan/PAN photo, via Associated Press
item.description: Militants, who are possibly holding five people, demanded that the government resign and that it release an opposition leader.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: E.U. and U.S. Urge Erdogan to Show Restraint After Coup Attempt in Turkey
item.media:description: Bodyguards surrounded President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey, center, as he attended the funeral of a victim of the coup attempt in Istanbul on Sunday.
item.description: Even before the weekend’s events, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan had represented a quandary for E.U. foreign ministers, who are meeting in Brussels.
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: What in the World: Business Owners Turn to an Unlikely Mascot: Hitler
item.description: The Nazi dictator’s image has been used to sell fried chicken, shampoo and jeans in places as varied as India and the Gaza Strip.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: What in the World: Visiting Madagascar? Leave Red Swimsuits (and Lemur Recipes) at Home
item.media:description: Behavior in Madagascar is governed by thousands of cultural taboos, or fady, that may seem random and superstitious to outsiders.
item.description: Thousands of cultural taboos, or fady, are crucial to the identity and worldview of the Malagasy, but may seem random and superstitious to outsiders.
item.dc:creator: BRYANT ROUSSEAU

item.title: What in the World: Never Mind Grass-Fed, How About Elixir-Fed Meats?
item.description: In China, meat from livestock fed on traditional herbal remedies fetches a premium price from health-conscious shoppers.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: German Police Kill Assailant After Ax Attack Aboard a Train
item.media:description: A firefighter in Würzburg, Germany, on Monday after a youth wielding an ax and a knife attacked multiple passengers aboard a train.
item.description: A 17-year-old Afghan youth who came to Germany as a migrant last year attacked passengers with an ax and a knife. The motive was unclear, the police said.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: How the Internet Saved Turkey’s Internet-Hating President
item.description: Who would have guessed that free online communication would come to Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s rescue?
item.dc:creator: ZEYNEP TUFEKCI
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Theresa May’s Shock Therapy
item.media:description: Theresa May addressing the media outside 10 Downing Street on July 13.
item.description: Britain’s new prime minister wants to make things better by shaking them up.
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW D’ANCONA

item.title: Editorial: Ban Russia From the Rio Olympics
item.description: A new report gives the International Olympic Committee all the evidence it needs to ban every Russian team from the Rio Games.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: As Refugee Family Resettles in Sweden, 9-Year-Old Nephew Dies
item.media:description: While a nurse prepares a medicine, Nabih, 9, rests in a hospital bed next to an aunt, his brother Farid and his mother Shazia Nouri, right, at a hospital in Antalya, southern Turkey.
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.description: Ahmad Majid is one of millions of people swept up in a global refugee crisis; his resettlement in Sweden ended when his young nephew died this week.
item.dc:creator: ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Insider Podcasts: Gone: Global Warming Claims a Lake — and a Way of Life
item.media:description: The dry bed of Lake Poopó near Llapallapani.
item.description: The Andes bureau chief, Nicholas Casey, and the staff photographer Josh Haner give listeners a behind-the-scenes account of their article about a vanished lake.
item.dc:creator: SUSAN LEHMAN

item.title: Srebrenica: 21st Anniversary of Europe’s Worst Postwar Massacre
item.description: More than 8,000 men and boys were murdered in and around the city of Srebrenica in July 1995, the worst mass killing in Europe since World War II.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Voices From Europe’s Far Right
item.media:description: “Our economy doesn’t increase along with the never-ending supply of immigrants,” wrote Mikael Jakobsen, 24, a law student in Aarhus, Denmark.
item.media:credit: Michael Drost-Hansen for The New York Times
item.description: Hundreds of readers from across the Continent responded to our call to share their experiences as supporters of far-right parties.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: Not Forgotten: Inside The Times Archives
item.description: Since 1851, more than 200,000 people have been the subjects of obituaries in The New York Times. Join us each day this summer as we revisit many of these memorable lives.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN
